overview_of_class: This course explores an intriguing problem in social scientific analysis: the production of new ideas and practices as well as the reputations of their creators: How do social and cultural contexts affect creative output and innovations? How do professional communities determine when ideas are original, instead of misguided or infeasible? How does this compare across the arts, the media, or the economy? Students will be acquainted with key approaches to creativity and innovation in sociology, organizational analysis, urban studies, and economics. Through a set of assignments, students also will build important skills for their own future creative research or professional work. The course will involve brief lectures, student presentations, discussions, and a collective interview with an invited creative expert.

overview_of_class: Technopanic! The alleged corruption and destruction of society by "new" technology. Hacking and trolling, mass murders and bullying, ADHD and antisocial behavior - What do these have in common? They are all social behaviors, occurring both online and off, which have, according to some, been brought about or exacerbated by our new media environment. Such deviant behaviors give some people ample reason to fear digital and social media. But is technology to blame? We will grapple with this question as we investigate how our understanding of new technologies and media is socially shaped and, in turn, how new media might influence our social behavior. By examining empirical evidence, students will develop their own informed opinions on whether technology is good or evil, or somewhere in between.
